Topic.Title: TOP FUND MANAGER. SMALL TABLET A BIG MISTAKE

Message.Msg: Sub 8" iPad will be very successful... very accretive to earnings/share value for many reasons... Will destroy the Kindle, Will easily take Top position over the 7" tablet space... another great way to turn things back around on Samdung, will find widespread applicability in professional areas where a 10" tablet does'nt seem as practical, will be more affordable to ppl who can't afford the premium model, yet another gateway into the Apple ecosystem, more iTunes sales... Even *if* it cannibalizes another product which really seems to have minimal threat, it will still again cash in with newer customers otherwise not actualized, who very well may in the future choose another Apple device as their compatability is so fun and flawless, and generate plenty of iTunes sales along the way cementing that likelihood. Even Steve Jobs admitted that if a product is going to cannibalize, it's best to cannibalize your own devices, which I for one find to make sense, and certainly proves to pay off one way or another with Apple. Fighting the 7.85" iPad is simply a losing proposition. This company and it's stock (especially) is simply godsend.🍀 See you @ $1000 and beyond...🌴

Message.Title: Amazon "Smartphone"... DOA
Message.Msg: Amazon has been chattering about this for quite awhile, and still seems a awhile away from it: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-07-06/amazon-said-to-plan-smartphone-to-vie-with-apple.html?cmpid=yhoo If it's anything like the cheap plastic crap Kindle is, then it won't stand a chance. Even if it's relatively nice which is unlikely, its pretty stupid to imagine that it'll effectively compete against even a 16 or 8 gig iPhone. Movies are not a needle mover for smartphone purchase decision making, iTunes music is the overwhelming choice, so not alot of threat there... They will have to more or less have to GIVE them away... and I hope they try... their margins will not be sustainable at all. Even barely decent androids that sell for dirt cheap have proven to be a losing game. I see no real threat from an Amazon phone... only to Amazon itself, but Bezos is a bozo, so if anything it'll be funny to watch. Face it, Apple simply rules.🍀

Message.Title: Did Apple Patent the Middle Finger as a Software Gesture?
Message.Msg: It's a funny topic, but today we find that in the software world; Companies have gone beyond copyright protection and have patented gestures, key strokes, and methods. In the old days, we just hired the software engineer away or we disassembled the code. Allowing patents to cover human interface including gestures and methods creates a problem unlike any other field out there today. First to Market isn't enough. Software/Hardware companies create a monopoly by limiting the user interface to other devices... This forces the consumer to accept a product from one and only one supplier and creates a forced purchase. If we allow this to continue, we will find that the future of all software products and how it interfaces to a device and the methods used to begin a function.... only available from one source... Then the price can be what it is.... for that mfg.... I think I'll call the patent office and apply today for the middle finger, held extended while all other fingers are closed..... He........ He......

Message.Title: Liberals, why are you celebrating Obamacare?
Message.Msg: Why, exactly, are they celebrating? Obamacare is far from the liberal ideal. In fact, many of its provisions fly in the face of what liberals say they stand for. The law promotes cronyism, hurts the poor, limits care for the elderly, fails to reach the left’s pet goal of universal coverage, wrecks havoc on government transparency, and raises taxes on the middle class. Remember Occupy Wall Street? Rowdy groups of young liberals gathered to “occupy” various cities in protest of the Wall Street bailouts and a political system in which the government and big corporations conspire to make rich people richer and poor people poorer. This wheeling and dealing cronyism is at the heart of the health law. Insurance companies supported the law, and in return made out like bandits. Thirty million new customers — like it or not — will be forced into their market. Liberals hated the mandate for this reason just a few short years ago. Remember candidate Obama in 2008: “Well, if things were that easy, I could mandate everybody to buy a house, and that would solve the problem of homelessness.” In 2009, Howard Dean called the Obamacare plan “an insurance company’s dream.” The mandate isn’t the only way corporate interests will profit from Obamacare. The “minimum essential” requirements for insurance are an open invitation to lobbyists representing each pharmaceutical and medical treatment to head to Congress — or state seats of government — to convince lawmakers their products are “essential.” If you think bureaucrats will be making these decisions fairly, considering only scientific studies or unbiased task forces, think again. There is money to be made. Not everyone will be making money from Obamacare. In fact, in spite of the income inequality “crisis” which supposedly keeps liberals up at night, low-income Americans will be among Obamacare’s biggest losers. Obamacare’s original design was simply to throw more people onto the already over-burdened Medicaid program. These people may technically end up with “insurance” through Medicaid, but given that fewer and fewer medical professionals will take on Medicaid clients, and more and more patients are about to be added to Medicaid’s rolls, they’ll soon find that having insurance doesn’t mean getting medical care.

Message.Title: relative strength beauty to behold
Message.Msg: The last two days we have seen sheer power and it bodes well for a run in the shares up to or possibly beyond the announcement of operating results on July 24. Relative strength is one of the most telling technical indicators and I love the action of Apple yesterday and today. This is a stellar performance. Fundamentally, who knows? The bloggers are holding firm on their above consensus estimates, but a lot of the concern around 3rd. quarter earnings is smoke considering that the lst quarter of fiscal 2013 should be a blowout number with product introductions and maybe China Mobile in tow at such time. That should give calendar 2012 EPS (through December of this year) of probably $49. to $52. Compare this forward PE ratio currently with that of the S&P500 if earning 104.00 for 2012, and you see how under valued AAPL is to the general market. And this is before the ex-cash factor which puts the multiple somewhere around 9.2X EPS. WOW is all I can say! Big J in L.A., retired security analyst

Message.Title: The economic ignorance gap between liberals and conservatives
Message.Msg: Good old John Edwards was actually right about one thing. He said there were two Americas. Under Obama, the John Edwards' thesis has come true. The first America is represented by those who work in the government sector (folks who almost always support Obama and vote for Democrats), and who think the private sector is doing just fine. The second America is represented by private sector entrepreneurs, small business owners, and job creators (who almost always support conservative candidates and causes) who know the terrible truth – the economy is in horrible shape. The difference between these two Americas is due to economic ignorance. To save America, we must ignore those in the government sector and start listening to those in the private sector who are living at "ground zero." They are the experts. They have the "boots on the ground." They understand first-hand what Obama’s policies have wrought: complete economic collapse. The dirty little secret rarely discussed or explained by the media and pollsters is the economic ignorance gap between what conservatives think of the economy versus what liberals think. Don't believe me? Just take a look at the opinion polls. Democrats think the economy is in recovery with a bright future. Republicans think the economy is in horrible shape, and worsening. How could two groups look at the same economy and see things so differently? Why doesn’t the media discuss this disparity? The simple truth is the media doesn't like the answer. The real truth is that Democrats, who are so eager to support their president, are either delusional, or more likely, ignorant of basic economics. Quite frankly, it’s hard to blame them. Most Democrats I know work for big government, a big union, a big corporation, or the media. They don’t sell anything. They don’t own a business, or work on commission. They are paid for just showing up, never based on performance or profits. They don’t know about budgets, profits, or losses. They get a safe paycheck every week, have a pretty much guaranteed job for life, and a pension when they retire.
